text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 08-1371, Christian Legal Society Chapter of the University of California -- Hastings v. Martinez.

Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: If Hastings is correct, a student who does not even believe in the Bible is entitled to demand to lead a Christian Bible study, and if CLS does not promise to allow this, the college will bar them from its forum for speech.
Now, these are fundamental arguments, and I don't want to spend too much time on factual matters because that's frustrating to both the Court and the counsel.
Happy to, Justice Kennedy.

But doesn't -- doesn't the one -- isn't the all-comers policy broader than the nondiscrimination policy, so that if you comply with that you automatically comply with everything in the nondiscrimination clause?
It is broader.

Yes, but -- but the latter, the nondiscrimination policy, you assert is -- is not viewpoint neutral, that it has a particular impact upon a religious organization; whereas, the other policy, the all-comers policy, applies to everybody, and that argument is not available to you.
Justice Scalia, our argument -- there are two policies.

But, Mr. McConnell, Justice Scalia had just made the point that the all-comers policy overwhelms the other, so that I would like you to deal up front with the all-comers policy that the dean in her deposition said, loud and clear:
--Well, both policies we contend are unconstitutional.
You can do that, but you -- it's a much different case if Hastings treats the CLS differently than it treats the Democratic and Republican Clubs.
Your Honor, it's a case where the -- where Hastings has put forward two quite different justifications for denying our right and both of them are unconstitutional.

Mr. McConnell, when I read -- when I read the papers that Hastings submitted to the district court at the same time that the joint stipulation was submitted, I saw one reference after another to an allegation that Hastings was applying its policy in a discriminatory manner, that it was not in fact insisting that all registered student organizations admit all applicants.
That's entirely correct, Justice -- Justice Alito.
Well, you should -- if that was it you should have brought in some -- some evidence of different treatment of other groups.
--Justice--
--There is none of that except your citation of the bylaws of two groups in your brief, as I--
--Well, but that is in fact the evidence.
But, Mr. McConnell, here is a statement, a stipulation.
--Justice Ginsburg, we -- we stipulated that this was their policy.
--I wish you would.
--Yes.
--the latter is the policy.
Yes, because the policy is I think blatantly unconstitutional.

So is this an exception that you want to talk about as it is applied to religious groups, or are you suggesting that if a group wanted to exclude all black people, all women, all handicapped persons, whatever other form of discrimination a group wants to practice, that a school has to accept that group and recognize it, give it funds, and otherwise lend it space?
--Not at all, Justice Sotomayor.
So then, what is -- what is wrong with the purpose of a school to say we don't wish any group that doesn't -- that discriminates?
--The stipulation is that they may not exclude based on status or beliefs.
So, what if the belief--
--that you just have to let you in that don't agree with you.
--What if the belief is that African Americans are inferior?
Again, I think they can discriminate on the basis of the belief, but not on the basis of the status.
You could have--
--if there were racist organizations--
--a student organization, I suppose, of that type.
--That's right, but they could not go the next step and exclude someone on the basis of status, under our--
Doesn't this say the opposite?
--It's that the group may not confine its leadership based upon its beliefs.
That's what you say, but that's not what the policy says.
--Right.
So you cannot discriminate on the basis of status or belief.
--The status half of that is perfectly constitutional and--
You say you--
--the belief half of that is not.
--you have to -- you have to let these organizations discriminate on the basis of belief.
What is -- what is wrong with that is that restrictions on a designated public forum must be reasonable in light of the purposes of the forum.
But this sounds like a debate over whether the policy as the school believes it should be implemented is not a good one.
There is a stipulation as to what the purpose is, and the purpose is to promote a diversity of viewpoints among registered student organizations.
And is--
That's their way of doing that.
It is a stipulated fact.
--And Hastings takes the position that it's all in favor of diversity, not only among the groups but within the groups.
Which is not the joint stipulation.
--It is that they--
It defeats the purpose of the forum.
--They say, yes, we believe in diversity among groups, but we also believe in diversity within the group; that's a good thing.
They say that in their brief, but that is not the stipulated fact in the case.
Let me make an imaginary example, and that's--
--Where -- where is the stipulation?
It's page 216 in the Joint Appendix, Joint Stipulation Number 8.
Wait a minute now.
"Hastings seeks to promote a diversity of viewpoints among registered student organizations. "
It may be--
--a global warming skeptic to--
--It may be an ill-advised policy, but the school says: It's our policy.
--They haven't happened because this policy came into being -- was announced for the first time in 2005.
--This -- this was not the policy on the basis of which CLS was excluded; is that correct?
That's correct, it was not.
It -- when they were refused participation in the -- in the student organization program, they were not told about the all-comers policy.
That's correct.
And was there any written document memorializing this policy prior to the time when the former dean gave her deposition?
Never.
And is the -- is the policy as articulated by the dean in her deposition the same as the policy that Hastings now claims it has in its brief?
--I don't think so.
Of course, that was not a religion case.
The separation is between church and state, but this Court has held over and over again that speech forums -- that people participating in a speech forum are not the state.
You're not--
Anyway, as I understand your argument on the all-comers policy, it is not an argument that -- that is based upon the religious nature of CLS.
--We would.
Or--

Now, we do -- there is in addition a free exercise argument, but I don't -- but in this case what the Free Exercise Clause protects is exactly what the associational freedom test would protect for everyone.
I had thought that an important part of the case, of your case, is that belief is inherent to the idea of religious expression and must be protected.
Again, separation does not apply to private parties when they are operating, even on government property.

Mr. McConnell, let's say it is the belief of this group, based on their reading of the Bible, that only white men can lead the Bible studies, can become officers of the group, and that's based on their fundamental belief that that's what the Bible instructs.
No, Justice Ginsburg.
But the belief is -- this is the belief.
They can insist that -- that everyone who participates in the group have that belief, and that, as Justice Scalia said, may mean it's going to be a very small group.
So, they -- they would have to negate their belief in their practice.
Well, it's not unusual to say people -- people can believe in all kinds of things that are illegal.
--This was the basis -- your distinction between status and belief was the basis for your saying that the original policy, whatever -- whatever we call it -- what is the name of it?
--The written policy?

The written policy -- when it forbids discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation was complied with by CLS because it would not discriminate on the basis of orientation, only on the basis of belief.
That's correct.

--If -- if a homosexual person said, I want to belong to this club, and I believe in its principles, I don't believe in sexual relationships before marriage, and that's why I want to work for homosexual marriage, which I do, so my consistency there, is that person -- I am consistent in what I work for, what I believe, and on -- as far as premarital sex is concerned, it's totally 100 percent with your organization that you are representing; would they admit that person or not?
Yes.
CLS doesn't have any -- any belief that marriage is between a man and a woman?
It -- it does.
No, no, no, no.
He shares the belief that there should be no premarital sex--
But he wants to marry--
--and he says that's why I am working for Proposition 8 or whatever the proposition, or against it--
Oh, oh, I'm sorry, Justice Breyer--
--I'm working to legalize homosexual marriage in which--
--I'm sorry.
--So they would not -- the answer is no, that person--
--Not if that person was engaging in sexual conduct that is contrary to the--
--No, he's not--
--Well, in that--
--because his sexual conduct--
--or -- I'm sorry.
--he will refrain until marriage is made lawful--
--Right.
--at which point he intends to engage in sexual conduct.
That's right.
That person.
--Regardless of what he intends to do, if he does not agree with the -- the organization on the point of -- of marriage, then he can be -- he can be excluded from leadership in the group.
--You keep talking about being forced to let people in.
--What I -- Justice Sotomayor, I believe what we consistently say is that we have been denied the right to meet on campus.
--But let's -- could we--
--there is not room for you.
--Let's -- let's assume, because I'm not quite sure what the record is on these issues -- I'm somewhat confused on the factual assumptions underlying this case.
Justice Sotomayor, even the access to campus communications is absolutely essential, as this Court said in the -- in Healy v. James.
There are bulletin boards.
--There -- there's -- there are ones for the -- for campus and student groups, and there's another one for community groups.
Are you disputing that this is--
We're -- we're barred from that.
--Are you disputing this is a limited forum, public forum?
No, it's definitely a limited designated public forum.
But that's different from Cantwell.
I only cite Cantwell for the proposition that belief is absolute.
--No.
I would address it.
Thank you, Mr. McConnell.

Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: This case was decided by both courts below on the premise, which is not disputed at any point in the petition for certiorari, that Hastings reserves the funding and benefits that go to student groups that obtain school recognition to groups that choose to admit all students--
Well, then why do you have--
--regardless of their status or their beliefs.
--Why do you have a policy, a written policy -- you don't have a written policy that says anything about all-comers.
Mr. Chief Justice, first of all, this is a case about injunctive relief.
Well, then why is--
--that both sides agree is in place.
--Is this nondiscrimination policy no longer on the books?
No.
That is not an implementation of the nondiscrimination policy.
--No, it -- Justice Scalia, this is--
No, what?
--It is operative.
Well, it doesn't -- it doesn't say that.
--It does, Your Honor.
Right.
--of the Joint Appendix: The college is committed to a policy against legally impermissible, arbitrary, or unreasonable discriminatory practices.
So they -- so you're saying the second paragraph is totally unnecessary.
--I think it provides additional guidance.
Do you think this case deserved a two-sentence decision in the Ninth Circuit?

--Justice Alito, it was decided in the wake of the Ninth Circuit's decision in Truth, which had not only garnered a substantial panel decision but had garnered serious consideration on -- on rehearing.
So the answer is yes, this case which is -- before us has produced hundreds and hundreds of pages of amicus briefs, deserved two sentences in the court of appeals?
--In the -- in the sense that it was backed up by the Truth decision, yes.
But hasn't it been -- hasn't it been CLS's position from the very beginning of this case that Hastings has not in fact required every group to admit any student who applies?
If -- if they believe that that caused the school to adopt a different policy, they shouldn't have stipulated to the policy that they did.
Well, they stipulated that the policy exists.
--All of the bylaws that they've pointed to, Justice Scalia--
All of the bylaws--
--that they have pointed to in their brief--
--Yes.
--Justice Scalia, either, number one, explicitly say that the organization will comply with the rules and regulations of the school or say that they will admit all students.
Well, they -- they quite -- quote the bylaws of the National Lawyers Guild, which says any member must
--There's a fundamental difference between a group that says people of a particular sexual orientation are not allowed to become members--
Well, they don't say that.
It has nothing to do with--
They don't say that.
--It's got nothing to do with sexual -- well, I don't know the National Lawyers Guild, but they say you have got to agree with the objectives of the organization.
--Justice Scalia, the district court made a -- may I?
No, start with mine.
Okay.
It seems to me that your position is continually evolving wherever the First Amendment pressure comes.
--Well, with respect, Your Honor, I think it's my friend's position that is evolving.
What do we do with the selective application argument, which is what Justice Alito referred to and Justice Scalia, which is it is troubling that some of these bylaws do limit their groups?
This case wasn't--
It's in the case, isn't it?
--Justice Sotomayor, this case wasn't litigated as a pretext case.
The -- the two are connected, though, Mr. Garre.
But--
And is there any other university in the country that has this kind of a policy?
--There absolutely is, Justice Scalia, and it's explained--
Where is that?
--It's explained in the amicus brief for the American Council of Education, explained in the State Universities amicus brief.
Well, there are very few universities.
Justice Kennedy--
And doesn't it work out that the Democrats -- they don't want to go in the Republican club and run for officership anyway.
--Hastings--
So why -- what's -- what interest does this -- does the school have in this policing mechanism that it's imposing?
--A few -- a number of things, Justice Kennedy.
But you now say--
--for all school-subsidized groups.
--You now say in your brief that it is okay for a group to impose membership requirements that are neutral and not based on beliefs.
That doesn't go to status or belief.
No, you're talking about--
--those are merits-based requirements.
--La Raza background.
The La Raza bylaws -- first of all, they did explicitly say that groups could not exclude members on the basis of sexual orientation.
Wait, wait, wait.

--Justice Scalia, it's based on the sworn deposition testimony on the former dean, who had been at the school since 1993, the director of student services, who had been there at least since 1999, as this is how they had implemented the nondiscrimination policy.
What we have is a rule, a stipulation.
Well--
--is they don't want to get into this, it's too complicated, and we're not doing that much harm to them because they can meet off-campus, and it's a big, disruptive influence, all of these things.
--Well, you--
--the more justification to know what it really is, which I don't have, what should I do?
--If the Court believes that, respectfully, we think it should dismiss the writ as improvidently granted.
But you -- Mr. Garre, you did say that the evidence is the dean's deposition.
--That's true.
Well, let's explore--
We're saying it's a constitutional--
--Let's explore the implications of this policy.
--Justice Alito, that's the claim, obviously, that the other side is making.

So if you have a law that says every newspaper that's published in the United States must be reviewed every day by the government's censor board, and the fact that the government's censor board decides not to do it, then that law is okay?
--I think this Court would ordinarily take into account the likelihood that something would happen, and if you're dealing where the only experience--
A newspaper sues saying that law is constitutional, and we'll say it's all right; it has never been applied?

--Of course this Court is going to examine the chill, but so -- just like in the voter I.D. case, where you had had people saying this was going to and, on secondhand accounts, did exclude people from getting to the -- ballot access.
That was because they might adopt a different policy.
And there's -- as to the takeover hypothetical, there is no evidence that it has happened.
That's not going to help if you have the 50 anti-Muslim students who want to take over the group.
--People have to be -- attend a certain number of meetings before they can join.
Okay.
--They can have in their -- they can -- sure.
Well, CLS obviously thinks this is a real threat.
--I think if that started to take place, the college would reconsider its policy.
No, do they have any--
--that would--
--Do they have any recourse?
--I think at that point--
If they have 10 members, and 8 who are completely hostile to the organization sign up?
--I think obviously the members would rejoin and form another group, Your Honor.
I understand the answer to that question.
--If that happened Your Honor.
It's also the--
--education.
--the university's across-the-board rules for all student conduct against disruption, against incivility.
Absolutely.
I'm sorry.
It's also never happened from, what I can tell, that someone who disagrees with this group has applied for membership.
Well, Your Honor, the record does show that--
I mean, that's -- that's what so puzzling about the -- the case.
--The record does show, Your Honor, that there was a gay student who was a member of the group.
That was the predecessor group.
The predecessor group--
--That was the predecessor group.
--and obviously uncomfortable with their position, so he or she left.
Well, actually--
That's the way it works.
--what the record shows is that she participated in discussions that the officer of the group said it was a joy to have her and that both sides learned.
Teach Bible classes?
--Your Honor--
You have to let them teach Bible classes, too, right?
--In fact, the record in the -- case shows that only officers teach Bible classes, and groups are perfectly free to structure their organization like that.
If an orthodox--
CLS--

--If an orthodox Jewish group or a Muslim group applied for recognition and the group said part of our beliefs is -- one of our beliefs is that men and women should sit separately at religious services, would Hastings deny registration to that group?
--If it was excluding students from that group on the basis of their beliefs or their status, then, yes, it would.
We have -- we have two amicus briefs from orthodox Jewish groups and a brief from a Muslim group.
Your Honor, I think even my friend recognizes that a group could not exclude an individual on the basis of their gender or their beliefs -- on the basis of their gender or race.
--Well, but that's because gender or race is fundamentally different from religious belief.
--But not at all costs, Mr. Chief Justice.
You phrase it that way.
--They -- there is a binding judicial admission.
Where -- yes, let's get back to this homosexual orientation.
--Look at page -- J.A. page 460, which is where the district court said that CLS made a binding judicial admission that they wanted to discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation.
What's supposed to happen?
Your Honor, I think it would be a much different case.
Yes, but what is your opinion?
--I -- I think if the school is regulating outside of the purposes of a limited forum, public forum for recognized groups, then I doubt it could go in--
So if, in fact, the -- the--
--and tell the groups--
--they have clubs and they're not services, and what they do is they discuss -- they discuss the -- the nature of the service, and there can they have separate discussions--
--Where -- where--
--men from -- men and women?
--Where the rule operates on a viewpoint-neutral basis.
I guess your answer to that is the orthodox Jews cannot.
--They can exist separately.
Outside of the university, et cetera.
--In fact, Your Honor, it's not -- it's not--
Well, that's their problem here.
--unusual for schools to have all male or all women clubs.

And their reason to put in a sentence as to why they don't want these orthodox Jews to meet separately on the campus -- men in one group, women in another -- and discuss the religious service -- they want none like that, and their reason for wanting none like that is?
Well, I think that's a much different example than this case--
Well, I'm trying to make it as close as possible.
--Well, I -- I may have misunderstood the hypothetical.
They have a small orthodox club.

--The reason why the school has a policy that all groups that it subsidizes must admit all-comers is that, number one, it ensures that all students enjoy equal access to all school-subsidized and school-recognized activities.
Can I ask about number 2, the -- the so-called line-drawing problem?
--Not with the all-comers rule.
I mean, the other -- it's whether you were discriminating on the basis of one of the forbidden bases.
I don't think it -- that happens at all, Justice Scalia.
As I understood the position, your latest position in your brief, you really don't say you have an all-comers policy.
Competitive-based, merit-based requirements are not excluded.

Could a -- well, could a group, consistent with your revised all-comers policy, require that members who want -- anyone who wants to become a member show a particular level of knowledge about the subject of the group?
--Yes.
So if the CLS required anybody who wanted to become a member to pass a test on the Bible, that would be okay?
--If it were truly an objective knowledge test, it would be okay.
Well, that -- that -- that's pretty tough.
I think it goes to the nature of whether it's discrimination under the school's policy, and I think status or belief.
If the school adopt an all-comers policy--
May I ask this question, Mr. Garre?
--for the purpose--
May I ask one question?
--Yes, that's the policy before this Court.
That we must do that to decide the case?
I believe you have to do that, because that is the policy--
So they're all--
--before this Court.
--There may be a lot of other things we can decide, but in all events, we must decide that much?
Absolutely.
--Well, could I just ask one quick question relating to that?
--If it's pretextual in the Church of Lukumi Babalu Aye sense, yes.
And what if we think that the policy has not been evenhandedly applied?
I don't think so, Justice -- Justice Kennedy, because that--
Is -- was there any proof in this record?
--No.
Let me just say, suppose it were shown that it were not applied evenhandedly, you'd have no problem with our saying that it's then unconstitutional.
--It -- yes.

If this were an employment case, and when an employee is denied promotion the employee said it's for reason A, and then after litigation begins the employer says, well, no, it really wasn't for reason A, it was for reason B because of a policy that we've long had, but there's never -- there's no written documentation of this new policy; and then at a later point in the litigation the employer says, well, it wasn't really either for reason A or reason B; it was for reason C -- do you think that summary judgment could be granted in favor of the employer on the issue of pretext?
--I think that that would create a factual issue and that that issue might well be tried, Justice Alito.
Well, I'm sorry.
I understood my friend's opening brief to acknowledge at the least that that's the policy the school has said it has today.
Mr. Garre, the -- the so-called written policy, that has a -- that list has a correspondence to the State's law, doesn't it?
It does.
The categories that are listed there are the categories that under California law are proscribed bases for discrimination?
It does.

Well, section 66270 applies to programs conducted by a post-secondary educational institution, and your position is that if -- if a religious group complies with your policies and then it conducts religious services, those religious services are conducted by Hastings?

Our position is that the registered student organization program is a program of the university; it's subsidized by the university; it's recognized by the university; and that all students should be able to enjoy access to that program.

In your response to Justice Ginsburg concerning California law, is it your position that California law requires religious groups to admit people who do not believe in their religious beliefs and in fact to conduct services of that group?
Your Honor, our position is that the provision that we've cited to, 66270, does not carve out an exemption in this program for a religious student organization.
So the answer to my question is "yes"?
--Yes.
Thank you, Mr. Garre.
Thank you very much.
Mr. McConnell, you have 4 minutes remaining.
Well, thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
Put -- put to a side a moment -- forget the as-applied.
Not facially, but as applied to CLS, yes.
Could you talk about -- I had understood from your brief that CLS did not have a -- a policy of excluding people with homosexual disposition, but that it was only homosexual conduct.
--That's correct as stipulated to, undisputed.
Well, you -- but your complaint said otherwise.
That's -- that's because we -- the complaint is accepting the -- Hastings' definition of sexual orientation.
--Oh, okay.
--not orientation.
Mr. McConnell--
--in order to--
--Mr. McConnell, you don't challenge that there are universities, including four law schools, that have an all-comers policy?
--So far as we've been able to tell, there is no public university law school in the country that has such a policy.
There are private universities.
There are some private universities that, according to the AALS, have such a policy.
It's not totally, if -- but it's imaginary, it's fantastical.
It's possible, but--
They say that we are going to apply that to everybody because that's how we do it.
--Yes, but Hastings has--
--if there are any ideological organizations that suffer--
--But Hastings has--
--so be it, but it's fantastical, and therefore--
--Hastings has a perfectly conventional RSO program just like the ones in Healy, and Widmar and Rosenberger.
--Well, my--
--of that program.

--my question is, if I can think of this policy -- but I tend to sympathize with your view that it's so hard to believe that they really hold it, maybe they do, I don't know about it -- what do I do with this case?
What can--
--how do I -- how do I evaluate that?

--What you can say is that Healy v. James requires a substantial justification for exclusion of a student group from a registered student activity forum, and this is not a substantial justification; it is a silly justification.
Thank you, Mr. McConnell.
